If you are a CISO and you have a 3rd party (Automation, AI, Analytics) that uses Sisense or you SUSPECT uses Sisense INSIST on an impact statement NOW.

Redhat points out CVE-2021-4104 is lower risk as this it is believed to ONLY affect applications specifically configured to use JMSAppender, which is not default, or when attacker has write access to the Log4j config for adding JMSAppender to the attacker's JMS Broker.

The good news is its likely all your mitigations, upgrades and other countermeasures will apply to JNDI exploitation of log4j v1.x (CVE-2021-4104. The bad news is if you assumed you were safe because you were on an older version, you should check again.

Log4j payloads are evolving fast, i have seen lots of obfuscation and encoding cleverness. You should only rely on WAFs or filers if you cant patch, and even then you MUST test and monitor for evasion. Its already being used to drop things like cobalt strike.
@RussoWasabi I know for a fact that there are large numbers of companies being breached by this. Even more are completely exposed. Just because its not in the news doesn’t make it any less real.

@RussoWasabi The news is the worst place to hear about whats actually going on. If it wont get views it wont get reported. What do you think is more important? A company like Equifax getting breached or the thousands of small clinics being breached every year?

Lastly log4j targeting is changing fast. This flexibility of use and rapid evolution makes it super flexible and useful. So naturally sophisticated attackers are now picking up on this and targeted attacks have been seen in the wild.

Many companies are having to take fresh looks at tech stacks because log4j can be hiding in the most innocent modules and just like loki it has many variants - largely thanks to copying and modification of the opensource code without returning the changes back to the project.

This is a really fluid situation and I think there is a real danger of underestimating or rushing risk analysis. Take your time and be thorough. This vuln can hit you in unexpected ways. I have seen payloads jump airgaps, exfiltrate over DNS and enter via non web apps like email.
